newsitem.title: UK: Med oil products lag crude rise,despite tight supp.
newsitem.headline: Med oil products lag crude rise,despite tight supp.

text.p: Mediterranean oil product markets failed to catch up with crude's gains on Tuesday and traded thinly amid tight supply, dealers said.
Gasoline was firm in a tight market with fair Italian demand lending support. An Italian refiner was heard to have bought an unleaded premium cargo from a French refiner.
"I think it will remain fairly tight at least until the end of May," said one trader. "We're still seeing the effects of maintainence programmes."
Suitable gasoline vessels for intra-Med journeys remained scarce with bad weather baving delayed loadings at some ports.
Naphtha remained sloppy in the near-term, but a number of traders foresaw a tightening in the market as June approached
Gas oil prices were unchanged to slightly weaker.
Traders said supplies were growing as expected with refiners coming out of maintenance and the arbitrage east closed.
Premiums to benchmark quotes for tighter Russian 0.2 pct cargoes were talked slightly weaker at around benchmark quotes high +$1 cif Genoa.
Premiums for well supplied EN590 remained soft at fob high EN590 quotes +$1.50-$2 a tonne with buying interest thin.
Traders were believed working high sulphur cargoes to the Far East and bunker demand was expected to bolster prices in the near-term.
"There is quite a lot of demand for better quality fuel oil in both east and west Med and not much supply," said one trader.
As in north-west Europe much business was on hold while players assessed the durability of crude's dramatic recent rise.

Refiners were said not to have woken up to the relative attrativeness of Russian straight-run material, which was well supplied but garnering little interest. Sellers were reluctant to push into the bunker market for now.
